mhQkMrp03iq2X-_FLtSZiA.text: I was pleasantly surprised by Tonkotsu. The broth is flavorful and they give you nice fatty slices of pork. The ni-tamago was good as well. The only gripe I have is that there were too much noodles and not enough broth. Great place for a ramen fix nonetheless.

vVFmnbHh-Q9k-xzrq3AB3Q.text: Ramen was ok as were the sides. Nothing to write home about.Service was awful. Waiting staff forgot to put our order for main courses in and as we were sitting outside they kept forgetting to come out. I had to keep going inside to remind them of our order that took 1 hour to arrive. Very irritating.Avoid

sNljVgjneEfXculZqnPHFg.text: Overall, I liked tonkotsu, but the bottom line was that I thought it was a bit pricey for what you get.The atmosphere was cool, but it was tiny and sitting at a bar with my friend was not ideal -- especially as she got bumped by waiters a couple times due to the cramped space.The ramen itself was quite good, but I felt that the portions were a bit stingy.  I am used to going to ramen places in California where you can get large portions of ramen for under $10.  Thus, £11 for a mid-sized portion of tonkotsu seemed pricey.  That said, I very much enjoyed the flavor of the broth which was satisfyingly rich.On the whole, I'm glad I went, but probably won't be hurrying back unless I get some sort of special offer to make lunch there a bit more feasible price-wise.

vO9_KwC8nGpGlTfP7M_BSg.text: Ramen and broth were good. However, pretty pricey for Ramen. Loved the half egg. Very tasty. Gyoza was a must try. The drinks were decent but service was really slow. Other places nearby that I would eat at before here if not much time in London.

MgYg6688ZUrKbAG-aSNB5Q.text: Of the 3 tonkotsu places that have opened relatively recently, this is clearly the worst. The soup bases are insipid without the depth of flavour that is the hallmark of this type of ramen. The ramen itself was on the soft and overcooked side. Service is very pleasant but doesn't make up for the very ordinary food. I suggest walking for 10 minutes to Shoryu or (if your legs aren't up to it) make do with Bone Daddies 2 minutes away.

98BZdAAcUKylm29K5VDxgg.text: I love this place,Warm and friendly service , nice decor and the Ramen as good as in Japan!Well Done

YTNitgtn-hvv8F6NT7yfyA.text: The tonkotsu broth was cold...hope I can find REAL ramen in 2013 here in London....

XsmGJkWie8ccKiU9PXdFNQ.text: Ok food maybe decent but leaves bad taste as service is rushed and poor. Does not even bother cleaning and wiping the table between service. No need to hurry for visiting

cUIJasRAtgbFsSfzsZXdKw.text: Good texture of noodles. Egg was perfectly cooked. Pork belly slices melt in the mouth but not much flavour. Tonkotsu broth is the most disappointing, it's greasy and lack of depth in flavour, it doesn't have the characteristic of tonkotsu broth that I know.

ClMz62_2UhvadIcNbuEIZg.text: Went back again, this time to try the soy broth, instead of the tonkotsu broth.  Again, it's difficult to really compare the two, but the soy broth is cleaner, less intense but the quality of the noodles stands out more since the broth is less overpowering.  Superb.  Really good.  Leagues better than Ittenbari with a similar broth.

Khhf1pVyxfOSqjNr5bKROw.text: I'm a massive ramen lover from Australia and there are some amazing ramen restaurants in Sydney.  It's been disappointing coming to London to find the cuisine I treat myself to, a big bowl of hearty soup, is very hard to find in London.  I work in Soho and when I saw tonkotshu begin to open the bottom of my stomach started singing with excitement.I went there on the second day it was open and ordered the spicy ramen.  Now when something is advertised as spicy I'm a little wary, I don't deal well with very hot food, but this bowl of ramens spice devil must have seen an exorcist and was long gone as I didn't even have as much as a sizzle.  I overheard the chef tell a customer that they leave the spice out and people can add it to their taste, sounds like they should have just called it a vege soup.  Coming to my next point, the broth.  I went back to try the tonkotshu after a disappointing bowl of vege with no spice ramen.  I always try the menu item that has the name of the restaurant on it a signature dish should be the one they are most proud of.  I too had the feeling the tonkotshu looked too pale and was disappointed with a very thin broth, it didn't have the porky flavour and it only just had the silky milk texture that a good tonkotshu should have.  The 2 broths i tried are too vegetable heavy in flavor and lacked salt, the spicy ramen tasted like carrots and celery, the tontokshu tasted more of vegetables than pork.  Something in me feels sad if I have to add a any salt based condiment to a bowl of Ramen.  It should be balanced enough that all I have to do is add spice if I'm in the mood.  I don't want to seem too negative but my bean shoots didnt taste fresh, the bamboo shoots tasted like brine and my egg white wasnt firm.  The pork was amazing but for over £12. Inc service for a bowl I felt a little empty.  I too rarely leave soup in my bowl but on both occasions I had to leave almost half my bowl of soup from lack of flavour and salt. It's a good try and I'll love to see it get better, but currently it's below average for the price they're asking, the only thing I love at this place is the decor and the 2 slices of pork in the tonkotshu, thank you British pork.

ZijCKTgYt5QVQZih-Q2yhA.text: The new dish- soho ramen was terrible! The fish was tasteless and the fishy taste was still in my mouth after one hr, and make me fel sick the whole day. The gyoza was all stick together and when we separate them they were all broken, it looks like they cooked it from frozen. They charge 10% service charge and I don't think it's worth it!

tbuG6YR2KbNCXJJO4_EVWQ.text: Is it ramen?  May be the cook overcooked the noodles the day I went there.  May be the cook needs to taste some other real Japanese ramen noodles in order to improve his noodle cooking skill.  Soup and toppings are OK.

UpUzNatw_yGycoRmyCJk2g.text: Pricey for what you get, it isn't the best ramen I've tried but then again I have travelled to the birth place of ramen on several occasions so it is difficult when comparing. I had the vegetarian miso ramen, soup was nice, not salty or overpowering, well done. Noodles were quite nice tasted more like soba noodles than ramen. The atmosphere is nice with the walls lined with Japanese style sheets and dangly lightbulbs.  Don't get why they cage their lightbulbs though, yes I'm talking bird cage which isn't Japanese more birdese.Service isn't great, I asked for water and she gave me a thumbs up but ignored me for a good while whilst serving other people instead. After an eye to eye the waitress decided to give me the water after the wait.Oh, and if you ever want to hear the gossip of London, you should definitely go here. It's like sharing a table at the school canteen and the guys next to me were talking about how their friend was sleeping around with another woman he worked with at the office. Interesting to say the least, over ramen of course.

u1B9xq-Y68dKQQ92t4dOPw.text: Given my experience of eating ramen before going to this restaurant was limited to Wagamama (urgh) and maybe one or two other restaurants, I didn't really have a high watermark to compare it to. I didn't really have many expectations thus. The menu is sparse, but seemed to be adequate and it's always refreshing to see a briefer menu. Something about it says "we're so confident in these few dishes we offer". My gf and I both went for the regular ramen, after starters of Gyoza, which was very nice. Next, we were both brought out a very generous portion of ramen, complete with a floating hard boiled (yet runny yoaked) egg. The broth was excellent, as if somebody had been able to distill the pure essence of pork into a liquid. It was almost too 'porky' tasting. Very very rich, but great. The pork belly and noodles floating in the broth were above criticism.They serve a nice range of craft beers and the pricing was what you'd expect for a hip new restaurant in the heart of Soho. Service wasn't amazing, even though our server was friendly, they seemed very hard to get hold of and somewhat forgetful. Shortly after trying this place we went to Ittenbari on Brewer St. which I preferred. I would go back to Tonkotsu, but perhaps only if we couldn't get in to Ittenbari I think.

20LY0RrGYvWVbVkTmrcW4w.text: I ordered their house special-the Tonkotsu-and it was pretty terrible. The broth was fine, but some of the ramen noodles were bloated and clumped together in a big mushy mass. This is a big no no. Texture is a big deal in ramen.The fried chicken was very good, but the ramen was very disappointing. No wonder there's no line here.

0o-PM0vMJr6LV88FyIzTLg.text: Delicious ramen, I had the tonkatsu it was flavoursome, delicious and quite rich - which I love. The fried chicken is always a favourite and certainly didn't disappoint. The ambience was calm, and light. It was quite warm inside as there were so many people in there, it was a cold rainy day so I didn't mind. I would recommend this place.

QcuXsC869BppxQs4g_4GNA.text: My overall judgement is that the broth is delicious, but the noodles were average.  There are only 3 main meals to choose from, but this is a strength in my opinion.  It is better when a ramen place concentrates on a few dishes which it does really well.We had a nice meal here, where every component went well together.  We each got a ramen, a couple of sides (gyoza and karaage chicken), a drink each and a dessert each.I have to comment again on the broth: it was awesome.  The pork was so tender and fell apart in my mouth.  The half egg was like a bonus prize which had an extra hit of flavour.  I was half expecting the karaage chicken to be overdone, but was very happy with how tender and juicy this was too.The bill was just over £50, which I thought was expensive at first.  However, considering all the stuff we ordered and how much similar meals would cost in London, it is quite reasonable.The service was very efficient.  Some may find the service a bit cold, but it wasn't rude and I was ok with it.  As soon as we finished, say, a single side dish, someone would be over within seconds to take the plate away.

o0f4qw0_8VBIkK1vu9OV5w.text: Gyoza: Excellent.Noodles: Good! They make them themselves, because an "old Japanese ramen dude told them to."Egg: Perfect. Like it, love it, gotta have it.However, the Achilles heel --Broth: the tonkotsu was watery!

NmeRtxfsWlc2Jni_bZ4daA.text: There were good things and there were mediocre things.Unfortunately, the mediocre thing was the tonkostu ramen which -- given the name of the place --  is clearly meant to be the star of the show.  The broth is fine, nothing more than that.  It has flavour, it contains no MSG (hurrah -- no thick and furry tongue!) but it lacks depth and the requisite creaminess that I expect from a good tonkotsu stock.  The pair of belly pork slices were as fatty as expected (some people love it, personally not my bag: i only do crispy fat so ended up nibbling the meat around off the fat), half soft-boiled egg and veggies were passable.  What offended my mouth, however, were the ramen noodles themselves: undercooked and rather dry which is paradoxical given they were swimming in broth.  The portion is also quite small and mine was not piping hot when served.The good things were the sides.  We ordered prawn&pork gyoza, chicken karaage, spinach and beansprout salad and the daily special, the name of which i did not catch but it was essentially a panko-crumbed filet-o-fish without the bun.  The dumplings, chicken and filet-o-fish were delicious.  Not greasy at all and the fish served with a homemade chunky tartare sauce (stingy portion but the servers were happy to give you more upon request).  The spinach and beansprout salad were a bit of a letdown with much more beansprout, being the cheaper ingredient, than spinach.I'm not sure if I would re-visit of my own accord.  If I want a dish of comforting, soupy-noodle slurpiness I think I would pick Koya.To credit Tonkotsu, one truly outstanding food item is their chilli sauce which is a sort of 'Nipponified' verson of Chinese XO chili sauce.  I scooped the stuff on everything, it was that good.  They should bottle and sell this goodness.

0dmyabkzkKHQObuOyccOpw.text: I've eaten here previously and quite enjoyed the ramen but when I dined again yesterday everything tasted different. Suddenly it was very bland, the noodles tasted off and the broth wasn't as warm when served. I was quite surprised especially because I enjoyed their ramen before and I'm normally very picky with my ramen but I might have to scratch this place out of my list.

Z0sEDrUMmu6F-4k7ZtgVdg.text: This ramen bar has been on my radar since last weekend's edition of Urban Junkies, and last night I finally had a chance to try it!All in all, I was impressed.  While not the best ramen bar I've been to (nor the cheapest), for London, this was good.  I had the Tonkotsu ramen.  The two most important ingredients were top notch---the noodles were fresh and chewy, and the broth was flavourful.  Tonkotsu have chosen to go with a very simple menu in order to concentrate on brewing a proper ramen broth (which takes lots of time and love), and I am quite happy with the trade off.  The taste of pig permeated that broth----I gulped that big bowl down, and the carnivore in me still wanted more.  RarrrrrrI was a little bit skeptical to try this place after reading another review here complaining that the broth was too salty.  I think that reviewer must have gotten a bad batch, because ours was "savoury" (or whatever the english equivalent to umami is) & not that salty....and I would say I have kind of a low tolerance for overly salty food.  I guess Tonkotsu will have to work on its consistency!I will definitely be coming back here to satisfy my ramen cravings...FYI Urban Junkies: urbanjunkies.com/londonThey send a newsletter every week with new restaurants, bars, events, etc for the weekend

OJGDIr_pvkOi2ybnLyMgBA.text: Not the best ramen I've ever had, but I thought it was ok. However, most of my friends didn't really seem to enjoy theirs (I had the tonkotsu, and most of the others had the tokyo and the veggie miso ramen) and one got really sick after, perhaps from the egg she thinks. So I've had to adjust this review accordingly. The soup was flavorful and the noodles were cooked to my liking, but the pork belly was just eh, and I found the gyoza to be lacking (mostly dough, hardly any filling).  The best part of our meal was the mochi ice cream sampler at the end. Three "little moons" - yuzu, salted caramel and black sesame. But who can go wrong with black sesame? I'd say, spend your time in the queue for a different ramen restaurant. This one's not worth the wait.

sGROWsnEWT8Envt4DrYICA.text: A Ramen Outing in London: Tonkotsu, SohoRubbish ramen is not new to Melbourne: this dish of thin wheat noodles in broth is a staple at Wagamama, for instance. (Hell, it's also what a Pot Noodle is, essentially.)But in London several restaurants have popped up here recently that are dedicated to it.In Japan, the perfect end to a boozy night out is a steaming bowl of noodle soup full of slices of roast pork, marinated soft-boiled eggs, beansprouts and spring onions. It might sound healthy, but it ain't - most ramen contains a hefty shot of animal fat.This noodle dish's status as the Japanese version of a greasy, late-night kebab isn't lost on Tonkotsu's chefs. The ramen at this new stall is big and bad, but in the best way possible.Owing as much to New York's current ramen craze as it does to Japan, Tonkotsu exudes machismo - echoing the Big Apple's noodle soup trend. A good ramen has three key components: a well flavoured broth, bouncy noodles and interesting toppings.Tonkotsu, a variety of ramen made with long-simmered bone broth (20 hours in this case), had a flavour so intense it was reminiscent of a Sunday roast, and marbled with lip-smacking pork fat. Testament to this soup's Chinese - not Japanese - roots, Tonkotsu also serves Tokyo Spicy - soy-sauce pork and chicken stock topped with pulled chilli pork.The flavours are big and bold; the dining room tightly packed; the staff are friendly - Tonkotsu is a whole lot of fun as long as you don't mind a short wait for your rightful spot at the table of ramen.

XNBHA3VCR2j2Sy0tWD-mfw.text: Went to Tonkotsu for dinner for a party of 3 at peak hours and was seated in little time, great standards for SOHO dinner waits. I ordered the Tonkotsu ramen which was really good (by London standards) as well as the Chicken Karaage (must order!) however the thing that ruined the dinner was the service, it couldn't get any worst and it all began with that one waitress...1. Ordered 2 ramens (but plenty of side dishes) for a party of 3 because a friend wasnt hungry, and the waitress gave us a frown 2. Told them water for everyone, returned with one glass3. Told them once again for water for everyone, returned AGAIN with ONE GLASS4. Forgot to put the Tempura into the computer5. Forgot that we ordered the Gyoza (despite putting the order in the computer)Finally, that same waitress decided to spray perfume at the counter on herself, we could visibly see that the perfume got onto other dishes (thank god not ours)So while the food was good, the prices cheap (again, SOHO standards), the waitress was so useless that I will probably not return again (unless the wait at neighboring  Koya is less than 15 mins)

glx07B07q3RZ00VklPzvCA.text: Good branding but bad service and food. Gyoza was fine but ramen was bad, especially the pulled pork spicy one. Did they forget to put the spicy sauce on my pulled pork?? It was dry and tasteless. The tonkotsu was very bland and not as thick as how it should be.The chili sauce condiment was good though...

g0LQm8s7Ycj9gQGoM-09mg.text: After reading so much about the ramen craze in London, I finally made it to Tonkotsu which was recommended by the Evening Standard and Time Out Magazine.  The decor is very hip, with rafter like ceilings and long benches for communal dining.  I can imagine the place very lively during evening weekend hours.  We ordered the Tonkotsu ramen, gyozo, pickled cucumber and spinach/sprouts salad.  In order of best to worst:1. Gyozo - I was impressed.  i think i believe that they are truly handmade2. Spinach/sprouts salad - refreshing, hint of peanut sauce3. Pickled cucumber - would rate higher if i could taste the pickled parts4. Tonkotsu - sadly underwhelming.  the noodles were tasteless, broth was ok.  only saving grace was the pork belly.  really unimpressive.So don't go if you are looking for great noodles...Chinatown is a 50 meters away for that.

MRTKEdJyeUmflUTAYcadfg.text: I really enjoyed this place, I was first a bit scared when I realised the staff wasn't japanese at all, but at last the ramen and the fried chicken were very good and tasty, definitely recommended.

hA51zuq4iqG3RUHjuKwEiA.text: The family enjoyed the food.  But, I thougth it was just ok.  The Spicy Ramen had a stringy meat which I had not experienced in other Ramens before. Thy Gyoza as nothing special.I was disappointed with the service.  We ordered four bowls of Ramen for my family of four.  The server brought three.  She asked me what I ordered.  I told her the Spicy Ramen and she said it was coming right up.   So, I assumed it was.   My family nearly finished all their food by the time I asked about mine.  Apprently, it was not coming up.  Very little follow up service after the three bowls were ordered and it was difficult to get their attention.  Then, there is a 10% gratutity charged directly to the bill.

8kXoCvrxmK4owMSGSkQaYg.text: I'll keep it short - really liked the concept, decor and the service was very good from the waiter we had. I really want these guys to do well and I feel that with a few minor improvements I'd be delighted to give them 4 or 5 stars.I've scored them 3 stars because we were disappointed with the Tonkotsu. I'm really fussy when it comes to noodles. The broth was ok but the noodles were not right - there was too much starch residue in the broth and noodles. My personal belief is that the noodles where not run under water just before serving like you would if you were making pasta at home. The net effect is that the dish doesn't quite like upto it's billing. The noodles didn't quite have the right texture. I was looking for a 'bouncy', chewy texture but it just wasn't there.On the plus side, the Tokyo was good and clean and didn't have the problems I encountered with the Tonkotsu. I would also like to say the Karaage Chicken was superb...even better than the places I tried in Japan. It was so good I ordered it twice! :-)

3H_0hg_ixCfAG1OPhHkDvw.text: When the weather is as cold and dreary as the one in London, you want something hot and comforting. Ramen is my go-to on a rainy day. The Tonkatsu ramen was good, but not great. The broth could be much thicker and more flavorful, but it does the trick. The agedashi tofu is quite yummy. Oh, I need to mention their cold noodle special in the summer time. Yes, I went there when the weather was nice, too. The cold noodle in some kind of sweet miso sauce was the perfect solution to a mid-summer meal.

nBQiszFMZOmSIbOdXjXsmA.text: I wanted to love this place. I was excited to have a new ramen-version of Koya, of which I'm a fan. Unfortunately. . . Cons: The broth is bland. It lacks the umami-punch that Koya broth delivers. Prices are steep for the taste experience on hand. Pros: Smiley waitstaff, fun industrial/casual ambiance. Garlic shots  love the concept of these and the concept of the restaurant generally. Nice try, and I'm dedicated to go back every few months or so to see if the taste profiles improve.

-5oKIStQgM_QrI53cYZNSw.text: The real deal for ramen in London.  Forget Bone Daddies or Shoryu.  Amazing pork bone broth, done right.  Those of you who've been to Japan will know what I'm not talking about.

r53BB68nORgI-CmP41cKtA.text: This new Japanese noodle shop in London is perhaps the start of the trend  a trend started when Koya set up shop a few minutes away, specialising in udon noodles.Tonkotsu does ramen noodles instead of udon. The menu is simple  only 3 different ramen noodle soups (including a vegetarian option), as well as 3 different types of gyoza, some sides, and a mochi ice cream dessert.The broth the noodles came in were probably the best I've ever had  so full of flavour, and it doesn't leave you with that dry mouth taste after the meal as its all natural and they don't use MSG. Even the eggs in the noodles were done to perfection  cooked and then marinated in soy sauce overnight.Service was a bit slow though  it could have been because it was a packed full house the evening I went. However, I think they could turn around orders faster than they did.Price-wise, £11 for a bowl of ramen noodles at first seem a bit steep  but given the quality, there's no comparison in London.Read my longer review at The London Insider with pictures!

BH-SayHjKOFtZIeH8uBc4w.text: I had the Tonkotsu which was very nice. My fear beforehand was the Ramen wouldn't of been able to fill me but half way through I was proven wrong! Very filling and good portion sizes too. Quite a small place so does fill up fast get there early or you'll be waiting for a table. Would recommend.

zjf_Y_qANCQh9Zw3JcamUg.text: It's fun and the food is warming, hearty and very tasty.  I'm no judge of how authentic it is, all I know is that I had a great time, the bill was very reasonable and the service speedy.I really enjoyed the eponymous Tonkotsu Ramen and happily took pictures of my neighbour's delicious looking Gyozo.  The only downside was that the coffee machine wasn't working so I was forced to drink Sake;)

KzIJW2ngIWhgD5ZBJsTrAg.text: tonkotsu is very good here, specially the egg.  Fitting since the name of the restaurant is for that dish! lovely seasoning, not overly salty as many ramen places are apt to be.  The raw fiyah ginger drink is a must have.

photos.caption: Photo of Tonkotsu Bar & Ramen - London, United Kingdom. tonkotsu.  steaming bowl of goodness perfect for a wet and cold winter weekend

ZRTjFsqFT4exHoLc6rB2_g.text: I've looked forward to the time I could try out Tonkotsu. When the minds behind this were still looking for a space and ran Tsuru Ramen pop-up to test out recipes, I was a frequent customer going to no less than 3 of their pop-up sessions. Each time, I loved the ramen that was served up, devoured as many servings  of gyoza and kara-age as I could, and revelled in the sweetness of the Umeshu and the dry crisp flavour of the cold sake. My main gripe was that it was bloody hard to get tickets for the very limited seating pop-up sessions so the idea of a permanent location serving such wonderful noodle offerings was A+ in my book.Unfortunately, like so many pop-ups/food trucks turned brick and mortar, something has been lost. I don't know if I should attribute this to the need to be more cost-effective, the difficulties in catering to larger numbers of people continuously, or a transition from owner-driven to employee-prepared. Whatever it is, the end result is a poor shadow of the glory of the Tsuru pop-ups and it seems that they've taken all the great research and feedback they must have got during the pop-up time (and I know that a number of Yelpers and myself had a long chat with one of the owners during the pop-up meal) and thrown it out the window. Even in its relatively short life as a brick and mortar, Tonkotsu has modified its menu with the most notable change being the replacement of the Tokyo Spicy broth (which alone was a reason to go) with a generic shoyu (soy-based) broth.First, this is a no-reservation place to be prepared to wait. We were crowded into the narrow entrance/exit portion  which meant you get pressed into everyone like sardines (think the Northern line at peak times) and even more so when someone tries to get out. The only benefit is that you get to watch the guys make the Ramen but the chefs studiously ignore everyone. Come on, guys, if you are going to have an open plan kitchen in the window and next to the line of hungry customers, get some entertainment going which would make us all a lot happier about waiting.Finally, after about 20 minutes, the two of us were lead to an upstairs table. Now they've crammed the covers in (which I don't mind too much) but it does mean there is no space for jackets, bags, and anything else you may be carrying (in my case, cycle helmet and some shopping). The menu is fairly limited with a handful of starters and sides and three types of Ramen: Tonkotsu (pork broth), Tokyo (soy-based broth), and a mushroom and miso broth. The gyoza looked a bit gummy (we got a close view of the table next to us who ordered it) so we opted for the kara-age and tempura prawns. Both were decent with a good crunchy coating and very little oiliness. Both could also have done with a bit more seasoning or perhaps a bit more sauce to dip in but overall an adequate start to the meal. Ramen-wise, we ordered a Tonkotsu and a Tokyo. I asked what happened to the Tokyo Spicy and was informed that I could just add chilli oil to the Tokyo to make it spicy. Now, first off, that's completely different from a broth that has been designed to be spicy and second, the chilli oil had about as much heat as a snowball.The Tonkotsu was extremely disappointing and lacked in flavour. Now I don't mean it wasn't as meaty as I wanted it to be, but rather that it wasn't meaty at all and tasted of water that may have seen some pork in passing. The pieces of meat were limp and greasy (not in a good way!) that made you feel as if they had been boiled down for the stock and then thrown back in. Which would be acceptable had there been any taste to the broth. The Tokyo was better although the meat was still disappointing. The egg was tasty and well seasoned but there were few veggies and the noodles could have done with a little more cooking time. I'd wager the broth wasn't hot enough before being poured over the noodles which caused this problem. A bit unacceptable when this is quite literally your stock in trade.The best part of the meal was the end, and I mean that only partially due to dessert. We got a selection of mochi to share: chocolate, salted caramel, and yuzu (a lemony fruit). The chocolate was good but a bit generic, the salted caramel tasty although could use a bit more salt for my personal tastes, and the yuzu incredible. Yuzu has a delicate lemon flavour that both teases and refreshes. In a mochi (a  ball of ice cream covered in a thin sweet and soft dough), the balance between sweetness and tartness is perfect.Drinks were average with two of the four cocktails involving umeshu, a plum wine. Which is fine, as long as you have umeshu...which of course they didn't. How do you run out of something that central to your cocktail menu at 7pm on a Friday? And if you do, run down the street to Chinatown or Japan Centre and buy it! So a drinks fail as our first two choices were not available and we ended up with some tea. Bah!

1Ccwsdah-7-raXI6k5UkJw.text: I stopped in and had a bowl of the Tokyo Ramen.  The noodles and broth were very good.  Oddly enough two of the three pieces of pork belly were very good, but the third piece seemed a bit tougher.  Being an out-of-town visitor in London on business I can't compare Tonkotsu to other Ramen options in the area, but I enjoyed it and would go there again.The place itself is rather small and somewhat unassuming so just go for the ramen.

tzd5FZnDmB65uVEZWI5YVQ.text: How much did I want to like tonkotsu? Way too much. My experience with new-wave Ramen bars in London has not been ideal. Traditional Japanese places seem to be the only ones who get the job done the right way. My Ramen-obsessed friend recently advised that they are so amazing because they make their own noodles whereas other places don't.Walking in and getting a seat was easy, post-Christmas London is dead and you can go anywhere without queuing.  Once sat down (mind you, at the back where each chair faces the wall) we had a look at the menu that was also written in Japanese. Japanese! These people know what they're doing!I took a minute to suppress my need to try the soft shell crab. I'm aware such places are not experts and I'm usually left with a greasy piece of white meat that tastes nothing like crab.Some slightly burnt pork gyoza and 3 crispy king prawn katsu later, I wasn't feeling the love. I couldnt see the sparkle in the food, but I only assumed this was because it was a starter and I had to wait for the mains. I went for noodles afterall! The king prawn katsu was proper nice though the sauce was way OTT. So I had them with some lemon juice rather. The pork gyoza were ah-k. Slightly burnt underneath and with the typical industrialised gyoza flavour you can find just about anywhere. Apologies, hand-made or not, I don't easily see the difference in it.My Tokyo Ramen arrived minutes later. I looked at it and I instantly sensed it needed something. Something more. It came with a few slices of green onion, 3 somewhat decent pork pieces, half an egg and some bamboo (oh and some manma that i dont know what it is).Tastewise, yes, it was good. It wasn't served in a Bone-Daddies-oil-laden-pool of a bowl but it tasted heavy of meat. I attacked the chilli oil and soy sauce and things got better.Halfway though, I had lost most of my excitement and I was just noisily slurping to finish off my bowl. The broth was OK, yes, but the pork had a massive slab of fat. Not the sexy type of charred fat, the ugly fatty type. I ate it all as I was hungry.I will most likely return, when Koya is not open.

GiCq6s41YlDEczwkz9MH5w.text: 3 and a half stars. Ramen is ok but not as good as the other ramen places I've tried in London. (Such as kanada-ya and shoryu.)

4jUTKr-NQAS-JO0m6cuEmQ.text: As you may have seen from some of my other reviews - I go on a monthly ramen hunt with two of my girlfriends.  During the year-long chill, this let's us gorge ourselves on yummy food thought the guilt!Service - Not bad. If I didn't have the great company, I probably would have gotten a bit annoyed by the delay - we were tucked in the far right corner upstairs.Note: Make sure you have your whole party with you before showing up - as you'll have to wait to be seated.Food: The ramen here didn't particularly stand out - if you're really pining for ramen in Soho, this would be my pick over Bone Daddies, which I find too salty. The best part of the whole meal - dessert. The mochi selection at the end (mochi wrapped around icecream): chocolate, salted caramel, and yuzu (a lemony fruit) - So so good. If you do pop in, don't miss out!

DcYnvgx7Ezn1nC9da7zX-A.text: So I came here two nights after going to Bone Daddies. It was not as good as Bone Daddies (which also wasn't that great).Ramen was really mediocre. Flavorless and bland. Had to add a lot of the hot sauce to give it some flavor. Also didn't have very many or very exciting toppings. Actually it was below mediocre. Cucumber were not vinegary enough. They also added these sesame seeds on it that were totally unnecessary. Maybe to mask the blandness of the cucumbers. Didn't work.Chicken kara-age was pretty good though. I enjoyed that a lot. The right meat to crisp ratio. Better here than at Bone Daddies. Would not recommend.

dxbiYCf9w7nhS9KRK3dqhg.text: I am an extremely picky ramen eater. However, I must say Tonkotsu is the best ramen in London. I've tried all the different ramen restaurants people have recommended me to, and I only have been satisfied with Tonkotsu. The noodles really are the perfect consistency, chewy and delicious, especially since they are made fresh. The broth is absolutely delicious and rich, a sign that it has been made over a long period of time. The egg is absolutely perfect and I have always been happy with my meal. I've introduced Tonkotsu to many others and they all have enjoyed it as much as I have. However, I am taking a star away because the service is not that great, yet they tag on a 12.5% service charge. The food makes it worth dealing with bad service though and paying a little extra for your bowl.

zIkXqrGr5ZEfio6Fb23Lfw.text: Tonkotsu did not blow me away - but offered a tasty, reasonably priced, casual bite in the middle of Soho. For non-pork eaters, there is a single miso-based broth choice... and it is delicious, coming complete with leafy vegetables and mushrooms. Combine this with an order of Gyoza (I went for prawn, but there is also a vegetarian and pork option) and a beer and you'll be set for a quick meal under 20 GBP. Service was average, but is hardly the drawing point of this restaurant.Many of the reviews here have centred around the noodle quality (or lack thereof): in truth, I found the noodles to be spongy (a good thing!) and well-prepared, albeit not the best that I have ever tried. Not great enough to gush about, nor mediocre enough to complain about. I wasn't expecting the best Ramen of my life, nor did I receive it. But make no doubt: this was a good meal. And I would go back again.

59O9-OK-H__l01WvISVA0A.text: Hmm, so there's been some disappointment with the Tonkotsu broth, eh? I went with the spicy style one, and I really liked it!Flavourful pulled pork, spicy, but not too spicy broth with nice depth, well-cooked ramen noodles, and a semi-hard boiled egg = really tasty and something I'd certainly return for when the craving hits. We also had the prawn gyoza and I thought those had great flavour as well-- no real need for dipping sauce, even. Real spice-lovers will probably be disappointed with the lack of spiciness, given the name, but I think even people who don't particularly like spicy will like this broth. So what have we learned, class?Listen to your yelpers. Get the spicy broth.

vXBo_GEiVH6kLVn1nSmTxQ.text: I photographed a pre-wedding engagement session in London a couple weeks ago. My clients were staying nearby at Soho Hotel. We passed by here walking through the streets and I noticed ramen! I love ramen and I can usually spot it in any city I go to.My friend and I decided to try it one night. I was a little hesitant because there was absolutely no one inside but across the street at the Vietnamese place was packed. I guess its kind of like NY, once its old, its played out and not trendy anymore.The homemade Tonktosu broth was nothing to write home about. It was very bland. The gyoza was probably the only memorable thing on the menu that we had. The dining area was beautiful and modern. The restrooms downstairs was a scary steep way down and very dirty inside.Staff was bleh.crave-o-meter 3 out of 10

AWBUWB3OvvYCl8Xnw3h3rA.text: Last time I went the broth was good, best I had in London.Went again yesterday and unfortunately nothing was right - slow service and bland broth.  It's lunch hour and I am not that forgiving to slow service.  Sorry, have to take away one star.  Ahhhh... the lack of good ramen place continues to be a problem in this town...

s7hmTvgPoljaMXDzRSlzmw.text: Wow! I woke up this morning thinking about something firm, tasty and delish! craving and wanting more! Yes folks, Tonkotsu noodles (Tokyo spicy to be precise) faaarking great!! This is a low key, casual Japanese eatery specialising in delish bowls of noodles served up in a pork broth (simmered for 18hrs to be specific) filled with flavoursome and tender shredded pork topped off with half a semi soft boiled egg & lovely tasty veg.They also serve Tonkotsu ramen (pork bones make an appearance here as part of the broth,think creamy, rich moments) which is also faaarkin delish!Sides of loveliness, including edamame, tofu, deep fried chicken to name but a few, are there to add to this lovely experience of food heaven (if you like noodle dishes that is, if you don't normally, give this place a try, bet it will leave you wanting access to this particular food heaven too).Sake is also star of this eatery, as are the lovely wait staff.Yeah, faaarkin tasty as faark! Love love love!!

CxahjK-xraMC5ce9ganqxA.text: Tonkotsu is definitely the real deal when it comes to ramen. They're doing 50% off until Sunday off all food, so get down there!We were lucky enough to get a table today after a short queue. The menu is very short - a selection of appetizers such as gyozas, edamame, and then two choices of ramen. You can choose from 'tonkotsu' or 'miso' broths. The ramen is really really good, and the broth is so flavourful. You can definitely taste the richness of the broth, and the egg is a bright shade of orange and with just enough gooey-ness. The pork is not too fatty + you get two slices of moist delicious pork. The noodles are definitely on the chewier sides as opposed to soft, which is how I like them cooked.Service was definitely slow - we had to ask for the bill twice, and the appetizers basically arrived at the same time as our ramen. I can't really deduct any points for that because they're haven't officially opened yet.This is definitely my new go-to spot for ramen. Highly recommended!

LyN61Jmi_GnU4HuEb-asCw.text: Noodles is not the type of food that I usually eat but if I lived in Lisbon I would definitely be a regular costumer of this restaurant :P

8H9a2Lsu0JR7rqFtf4uAZg.text: In a word, boring. It promises a lot. And looks rather nice from the outside too. But it's nothing special. Don't be fooled by the cheeky bit of hiragana on the menu, nor the implicit focus on the broth by putting the soup maker dude at the front of the place. I had the tonkotsu and the pork gyoza. The gyoza were okay, but not really much better than buying frozen gyoza from Japan Centre and making them myself. The tonkotsu was starting to head in the right direction, but didn't really get there. The broth was slightly porky, but frankly far too healthy. Proper tonkotsu should have fat globlets floating on the surface. It was also rather too bland. Yes it had pork flavouring to an extent, but it ended there, abruptly. Thank god for the garlic and the chili. Alas an opportunity to make it taste like it should. Not enough broth either, nor egg. Apparently they used to do a whole egg with the dish, is an extra half egg that much of a stretch these days? Oh and the chashu (pork). Boring boring boring. Just do something with it to make it more interesting. Smoke it, maybe cure it a little. But it's dry (somehow!), lukewarm and disappointing. But hey, let's look on the bright side here for at least part of a paragraph, it's a hell of a lot better than the 'ramen' one expects from wagamamas/pot noodle, and it's showing that the London ramen scene is vaguely starting to head in the right direction. There's just a lot of work to be done. Oh and it's pricy, even compared to Tokyo. Next stop, bonedaddies.

qjRhEAvBNNUwDr94VToQEQ.text: For all the new ramen options in Central London these days, I was sort of surprised by how amateur Tonkotsu seems to be. The noodles were undercooked and chewy in both my husband's signature ramen and my Tokyo ramen. The pork was chewy and very fatty--not nicely marbled, just fatty. The waitstaff also took great offense to being told that their tapped Asahi had gone awry. The flavor was very metallic. After my husband didn't drink his, the waitress tasted it with a straw and declared it to be fine. We paid for it anyway. And while I'm on the subject of waitstaff. Maybe they could find a more appropriate time to walk about whinging to one another about their work schedules. Just a thought. The only bright spot was the karaage. While a tad greasy, the coating was flavorful and crunchy. However, fried chicken alone is not enough to make me come back here.

__JsakGCZiBGaSxj8nRySg.text: Two floors of a vibrant steamy Japanese noodle bar with a buzzing atmosphere. A feel of street food and full of rich aromas. Prawn Katsu and pork Gyoza starters followed by the eponymous house special, a rich pork broth (prepared for 16 hours with herb infused Lardo) laced with braised pork belly. All consumed in front of a busy open kitchen. Reasonably priced with affordable house wine (and saki!), a great way to start or end an evening.

photos.caption: Photo of Tonkotsu Bar & Ramen - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Tonkotsu Bar & Ramen - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Tonkotsu Bar & Ramen - London, United Kingdom

m-f80kToluizx2HKBXb46Q.text: As a ramen junkie from NYC, I've been exploring the ramen scene in London and have been very impressed. I am a fan of tonkotsu ramen so I had to check out Tonkotsu! If they are confident enough to name the restaurant after their signature then it must be good!I stopped in for a late lunch (no queues) and ordered the tonkotsu ramen, pork gyoza, and an Aspall Cider (goes great with pork). I sat outside and got a great view of the busy Soho streets as I ate!The gyoza came out quickly, and they were hot, fresh, and crispy. The skins were a bit thicker than I like them, but that's not really a huge gripe. I wish I could have mix and matched the various flavors so I could try all the dumplings, but I understand why they couldn't do that. They were great with soy sauce, rice vinegar, and chili oil.The tonkotsu ramen had a shio tare, and I detected a lot of ginger in the broth as well. It was relatively rich and was pretty good. The noodles were cooked well (though I usually like them to be a bit harder), and it was topped with bean sprouts, scallions, bamboo, chashu, and half of a soft-boiled marinated egg. Solid bowl of ramen.I liked that when you order kaedama (extra noodles), they bring it to you in a bowl with some more broth. You don't usually see that, and it's pretty generous.The staff was very friendly and I chatted for a while about ramen in general and learned more about the industry scene here.Strong spot for ramen in London for sure!

GsBBQt7WyJU4ekEnd4WzaQ.text: Having lived on authentic tonkotsu ramen in Japan for 3 years, I was so happy when this place opened up. I've taken friends here and have been many times myself. Along with just one other place in soho this is authentic Japanese fodder, at least as authentic as you'll find in London; one spoon of the broth and I'm back in Oita. The waitress was so accommodating of my group, one friend didn't want the broth, so had some sides and then the ramen without the broth, no hassle at all! The gyoza were delicious and the Asahi on draft topped the experience. Make a night if it and pop to karaoke box around the corner after for a night of Japanese fun!

photos.caption: Photo of Tonkotsu Bar & Ramen - London, United Kingdom. Incredible, authentic tonkotsu ramen in London.

oUs0ZvYIqvwPqBaxPf4cfw.text: This ramen place comes 2nd to Bonedaddies for me. I liked the broth for the Tonkotsu ramen, but would like the pork to be more tender. The ambience is nice, we went on a rainy Sunday lunch in winter time so there were little people. Not sure how this place might be in night time. Would recommend this still.

photos.caption: Photo of Tonkotsu Bar & Ramen - London, United Kingdom. The bar
Photo of Tonkotsu Bar & Ramen - London, United Kingdom. I like the broth (16-hour!) for this Tonkotsu Ramen. The pork itself can still be more tender (for me).

xvGQ-a-9riAYsghqymopVA.text: If Bone Daddies is full then don't fret, ramen is but a couple of streets away. So may even say it's better but since I can't yet compare I'll have to save that view for another day.In any case the gyoza are simply divine and the house ramen is definitely the one of choice. I would say that compared to ramen in Kyoto it's a bit saltier and it would be nice to have more than a couple of thin slices of pork. Then again it does make for a healthier meal out option and you'll not feel hungry. Is this in my top places to eat... Perhaps not. Although it's probably something I'm going to eat more of as the weather gets colder.

ICKGFPjiAIWmjaSy9LucYA.text: I'm glad I didn't read other reviews but took just the opinion of my friend. A friend who knows the amazing ramen we love from NYC and is almost always disappointed with the ramen in London, like I am,No queue. Lucky us! Began with some prawn gyoza to share. And then my main, a nice pot of tonkotsu ramen. Oh yes, the broth looked milky (not the weak nearly transparent stuff elsewhere in town). Anticipation...So much pork. It pulled apart so I could put a bite with each mouthful. The noodles are homemade (look to your right when you walk in) and are cooked to the right consistency. And the egg, just shy of being fully cooked. Perfect.Seriously this was the best ramen I've had  in London. Yes  it's £11 but it's a nice ambience,not rushed at all, and really good.And do not shy away from the chili oil with bits! It's not that spicy and so yummy. I bought two jars to bring home. The manager couldn't have been nicer to make the jars fresh for me and engage I so me conversation - about the personalized photo on my credit card.I left full and with a smile. Well done Tonkotsu.Oh...my big thing about refilling water. A+ to our waitress who came round often  and without me ever noticing!

6PTgmuz1jT0HcmCr1SpVZA.text: I've tasted many different ramen and I know how varied they can be but Tonkotsu showed me a whole new flavour spectrum. Although it was different from any other, it gave me all the lovely ramen comfort of a thick, flavourful broth, fresh veggies, and filling noodles. Every element was unique, from the aroma of the broth to the texture of the noodles. The mushrooms in my Shimeji, Shiitake & Miso Ramen were extraordinary and the smoked haddoc crowning my friend's Soho Ramen was simply amazing too.Although we were seated upstairs, where the atmosphere is less cozy and the air conditioning a bit cold, the interior is nice and modern and the staff is friendly.As there's no more than a choice of 5 different ramen (2x pork, chicken, fish, and mushroom) it's logical that there's only a single vegetarian version but I think it was good enough to make me return for that one.

J0YxWGyAha8Bqy57-A8krg.text: I love Tonkotsu, as I know origial Tonkotsu rame in Kyushu, but this place is so convenient when you are hungry between shopping. Ramen is tasty & very quick service, but I just can't help wishing they can add an option for Beni Shoga (red pickled ginger) - without it, Tonkotsu Ramen is not complete.

photos.caption: Photo of Tonkotsu Bar & Ramen - London, United Kingdom. perfect quick snack / lunch between shopping. With a glass of wine, of cause.

W3Dkg8OtuVoYjeu8vvOfuw.text: Really fantastic, warming ramen.  Pretty decent broth, and the ambiance is quite good on evenings any day of the week.  First ramen recommendation for folks in the city.

UweTD4lwQ8Ur3sYeVVP-PA.text: I had the Ramen and I really enjoyed it. I cannot make comparison with other places because this was my first Ramen experience but I have to say that was very good. The restaurant is quite small although I liked the atmosphere. I had no problem with the service. If you are not confident with this type of food this might be the right place to start with.

photos.caption: Photo of Tonkotsu Bar & Ramen - London, United Kingdom

3Z_L5DzgSR3OhVNcBNQFaA.text: A very nice place, warm and friendly team and great food with good choices and wonderful taste.

hUh6seqyfwBk_xX6NZiYkQ.text: Where to start? This wasn't the worst Ramen I've ever had. The noodles and broth were ok. It was the toppings that ruined it. Mainly the BUG my friend found in his. Yes, there was a fly in his bowl of ramen. I'm sure this happens in the nicest of restaurants, but when it's you, it's not okay. The flavor of the egg just wasn't that great, and the pork was a little tough. This might be because they don't slice the pork here. Most ramen I have had the pork is sliced thin. Here it comes in big chunks.So why two stars and not one? The service was great. You could tell he was truly embarrassed and sorry about the bug. He comped both of our meals, and kept apologizing. Was it enough to make me go back? Not a chance, but not because of the fly. I'm sure that wasn't supposed to be there.  It was the toppings that were there on purpose that truly disappointed me.

photos.caption: Photo of Tonkotsu Bar & Ramen - London, United Kingdom

e0lX4BYTKG4zuZjPbmvu5w.text: I have tried ramen at a few really good NYC places, and then here, and I must say I was quite enamoured by it's flavours and taste. I also tried pork gyozo, which is again superlative, and topped it all off with the 12 year old Yamakazi whiskey, voted the best of 2014. Didn't find the whiskey that amazing though, but it is smooth and will give most premium scotch a run for their money.

photos.caption: Photo of Tonkotsu Bar & Ramen - London, United Kingdom. Tonkotsu Ramen. Heavenly pork broth.

SgzBqk0zjnzuP0AhxawPRw.text: I promised an update when I re-visited after the restaurant had officially opened. I last visited on their soft opening week.So, what changes? Firstly, they've opened an upstairs seating area though I was seated at the kitchen counter. This area was actually a bit disapppointing - most chef's counters are fun because you can see the chefs hard at work, which is great for a foodie like me and sometimes you get teh chance to chat to them. The chef's counter at Tonkotsu is very low and it feels quite isolated but fortunately, I had my iPhone to entertain me as the lighting was too dim to readMy favourite style of ramen is tonkatsu ramen. Incidentally, Kevin L and I weren't sure whether there's any difference between tonkatsu and tonkotsu ramen and he thought it may differ according to whether beef bones are used in the making of the stock. In any case, I love that the most because a good tonkatsu stock is so full of fatty goodness and flavour which comes from boiling it for hoursI supplemented the ramen with some tofu. Described as silken on the menu and home made by the waiter, I was glad to be able to confirm that the large slab of tofu was indeed very smooth - the toppings of bonito flakes and spring onion were enhanced with a little dash of soya sauce, on advice from the waiterThen came the piece de resistance - the tonkotsu ramen. The first impression was that the stock looked a little pale, unlike other tonkatsu ramens that I had eaten. However, I dived in with an open mind and it was certainly a big improvement on the Tokyo spicy ramen I had had before. It tasted meaty but still lacked the power and wholesome artery-destroying goodness of the stock of somewhere like Cocoro. However, in mitigation, the pork chashu was really tender and the egg was yolk-quiveringly perfectI was struggling to decide on the final star rating when I suddenly realised the acid test. When I leave Cocoro, the bowl is empty because I've slurped every last drop of the stock but at Tonkotsu, the stock remained in the bowl. So, despite Tonkotsu being £2 cheaper, Cocoro still holds the 'Yee Gan Best Tonkotsu Ramen in London' title

photos.caption: Photo of Tonkotsu Bar & Ramen - London, United Kingdom. Tonkatsu ramen
Photo of Tonkotsu Bar & Ramen - London, United Kingdom. Tofu Hiyya Yako
Photo of Tonkotsu Bar & Ramen - London, United Kingdom

n25X8DhyzwwphTQjQxq20w.text: Very average bowl of ramen, below par dessert with mochi ("three little moons") and poor customer service. Came here on a Saturday night, and there were no lines (though the waiter staff did tell us in a condescending tone, "here's how you form a queue - one after the other - see, that's how you queue"). Ordered the bowl of Tonkotsu ramen - the soup was not as thick as expected and noodles were bland. The mochi was the lowlight of the meal - they were completely frozen and even after letting them sit at the table to defrost, the taste and texture were below standard.

HiK5ntiT3xXjAzNmbC2wvA.text: Tonkotsu is just one of places in London's new ramen scene.  If a restaurant names itself Tonkotsu, you have to order their signature bowl.  The ramen was pretty good: rich, flavorful, porky soup with thin noodles.  I prefer chewier noodles and thought that the soup was a bit salty, but overall, it was a solid bowl.  However, with so many fabulous ramen places around London, I'm not sure if I will be back at Tonkotsu again.

photos.caption: Photo of Tonkotsu Bar & Ramen - London, United Kingdom. Tonkotsu ramen (11)

WBDgMBLexCG1Gx5w7ZtFsQ.text: If there isn't a queue outside and you are looking for a place to eat, pop in, you won't be disappointed. I came for a quick late lunch and was seated immediately. The Tonkotsu I got was full of flavour, the broth was insane and each different topping worked well together. What I love about this place is there are no hidden extras compared to other places which make you buy extra eggs and meat for your dish. As I said above, this place is very popular so expect a queue outside at peak time. (Visit - 18/07/2015 Lunch)

8XJyslZEXwFVdEh4usEZOQ.text: I really had quite high expectation of Tonkotsu.  I found the small menu really appealing (why have everything when you can focus on what you do best) and the passion that seems to be behind the food.  We had ramen plus a few sides.  The ramen was probably the greasiest bowl of noodle soup I had ever encountered.  The fat had not been properly skimmed off the stock.  Also, the soup stock lacked any real depth of flavour which was disappointing.  The noodles had great texture but without a fantastic soup base to match, it just didn't hold together very well as a dish.  The gyoza were also disappointing.  They reminded me of the ones you get in the frozen food section in Asian markets.  The service was friendly but not very good.  A friend's soup was forgotten somehow despite us re-iterating the order twice to the waitress.Overall, Tonkotsu has potential but not in its current state.  I won't be going back.

MJ2jcGifWBAfCIlHPuoDsg.text: I would recommend the crab kokkoke and the chilli chicken rice. The tonkotsu ramen is pretty decent from what I expected. I was expecting delectable gyozas but they are just okay.  The service was good and the place had a nice ambience to it.

PWw3jjjgP1Zcp3SJkaCnqw.text: Another ramen place in the ramen desert, aka London.  It tries but everything about it a bit off...  the other ramen places in the area are not that much better but I gave 2 star for this because:-  Ramen portions are small-  Soups are too salty and greasy to enjoy-  Noodles are too soft...-  interior is too darkIt has other dishes but quite limited - not as expansive as Shoryu.  For this reason, I gave two star...  but if you are craving for ramen and had tried the other ramen places in the area... you should definitely try and see it yourself and see what you like.  It is matter of your personal taste to see which of the not-so-great ramen that are on offer in London is closest to your preferences.  :-D

QfL3LAdKIuwZrakWvE8KMQ.text: Great Ramen Shop in Soho!We tried the Chili Chicken and Seafood Ramen. The food came out really great and the service was prompt.Seating is limited and we were seated outside which was good.

photos.caption: Photo of Tonkotsu Bar & Ramen - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Tonkotsu Bar & Ramen - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Tonkotsu Bar & Ramen - London, United Kingdom

MgcT6KcGwoeC6DthNeZplg.text: The ambiance seemed fairly authentic and maybe it was the authentic feeling that set my expectations very high. The menu explained that the home-made ramen noodles were cooked exactly 32 seconds and to tell them if you wanted something different. They also said, that any shop that didn't make their own noodles was just a soup shop.I ordered pork fried gyoza and their tonkotsu ramen - what should be their key basic order.The gyoza was fine. It was what you might expect in an average ramen place in Japan. Slightly small and on the light side.The tonkotsu ramen wasn't too big, which was fine for me. However, the soup was really thick. Tonkotsu stock is made from pork bones and lard so it is traditionally fairly thick, but this was unusually so in my opinion. It was also very un-salty --- this isn't a bad thing, but tasted kind of "off" for my palette. There was soy sauce but no extra salt on the table so I couldn't "fix" it. My slightly outdated impression of the UK was that everything was salty but maybe that's an old impression and London has swung the other way and become sodium-conscious, but the soup was very salt-free from a Japanese ramen baseline.The noodles with skinny and cooked just right. No complaints there. The roast pork was fine - fairly standard.They had a Tokyo style chicken ramen with clear broth which I might try next time.I'll try again sometime and try another ramen. I won't be ordering their signature tonkotsu ramen again, though.The staff were friendly and there were lots of interesting things on the menu such as hiyashi (cold) ramen and interesting cocktails that I'd like to try.

FeU8aBJOrMk5A49FHa8eCg.text: Been to Dean St a few times and was always intrigued if this ramen place is nice so we gave it a go tonight. Ordered the pork gyoza, chilli chicken wings and Tonkotsu ramen. The gyoza was quite nice, but wasn't blown away by it. Thought the wings were really nice and tasty - that I recommend. But this is a ramen restaurant so this review is all about the ramen. The broth looked very rich but was disappointed by the taste - it was bland. The noodles were nice, bouncy but firm. Sad that the broth didn't deliver the taste. I'd come back for the chilli chicken but not the ramen.

E38pU0Esx_-k8CgCcgC8BQ.text: The tonkatsu is the way to go, I went with the seafood ramen and regretted the choice. Tasted my friend's tonkatsu ramen and it was amazing. Noodles have great texture.Tiny restaurant, sharing tables is expected. Great alcohol selection and tasty chili oil.Go early, long lines at peak times.Menu pics attached.

t7YSm4A3fivAW2B9mxyZmA.text: This was the first place I ate at on my visit to London and I can't say that I was too impressed. The ramen wasn't bad, but it wasn't great. I ordered the tonkotsu and found the flavor a bit bland for what is supposed to be 16-hour long marinated base. The portions on the starters were also quite small for the price, although they were very tasty. After all was said and done, the waitress didn't give us a check after clearing our table for probably about 15 or 20 minutes, while we sat there waiting, empty table and all. She walked past us multiple times without gauging that it was time for the check, until when I finally asked her she responded "oh, had you already asked?" which seemed to imply that it was our faults for not asking her in the first place. I thought maybe it was a U.K. thing but since going to other restaurants and being handed a check as normal after food is eaten, decided that the service just wasn't very good at Tonkotsu.

photos.caption: Photo of Tonkotsu Bar & Ramen - London, United Kingdom. Tonkotsu ramen

vW0GOwTV8GQ76BNIZlrgMQ.text: I came to Tonkotsu with a few friends for dinner to try some ramen in London. I ordered the original ramen and my friend and I shared pork gyoza. Everything was really good! The ramen was just really really rich, so I couldn't finish half of it. The gyoza was so easy to eat, I popped them in my mouth so fast! I only gave Tonkotsu 3 stars because the broth was so rich I couldn't finish it, but the flavor of the broth was great. If you can handle really fatty broth this is the place for you!

tfgxlQItjlOpI_GLomjnqg.text: Great experience !Very nice people, very good food very tasty (the gyoza were extra), nice and cosy place.And the prices more than ok! Basically I was totally full for 15£I will definitely recommand to give it a try if are in the neighbourhoodOh, btw, the chilli chicken ramen, is spicy.. be aware eheh!

KtIzgY3jmhQQyCVtXzm31A.text: All the restaurants we pretty full on that weekend. Finding a table was nearly impossible, especially with our dog. So we looked for a restaurant with an outside table. After not finding any on the restaurants we preferred, we took our chance here, didn't check any reviews in advance.We only waited a few minutes until one of the two tables outside were available. It's not a big menu they have. Mostly Ramen, some Gyoza and a few sides. But that's fine, better have a small menu and do it right.We've been in Japan before and know good Ramen. It's not an easy thing to get right. So we didn't expect anything. But the Ramen (the "Tonkotsu") turned out to be pretty good. Flavours were good and the broth quite rich. It's not on par with the real Japanese Ramen, but for what it is, it was a good meal. Could have had more "oomph", could be richer, but for a Ramen Shop in Soho, London it's not a bad meal at all. For drinks we had some Sake and Asahi.Service was a bit unexperienced, but very friendly.

efQYjWjJ5w0dE3RzWLlAOw.text: Traveling during the winter, if you're cold this may just hit the spot. Granted it's the combination of cold weather and eating soup that makes it a lot better than it really is. If Ichiran and Ippudo is what you're expecting, look no further here's the generic off brand. Lukewarm, bad execution on the egg and chashu pork, with a bland imitation broth, I should've know better the moment I noticed there was not one single Japanese cook or server in here.

cfUvNSSK0RIl6NsLBqCXjw.text: I'm here for lunch. Ramen is good and the broth is delicious! I thought I am in the WWII era. There is a white peoples and Asians sections. On the back of the restaurant is all white peoples are seated on the back! But, Asians are sitting on the front. I had never felt so bad after a bowl of ramen. Is the Asians are less or doesn't get deserved to have better seating in the restaurant!! This is 21th century!!

GuWd_opz2BcoPuasrBrSVw.text: I tried the one-off special Iberico Pork Ramen.  It was a westernised ramen, arrived lukewarm - the stock must be hot! - but had very clean taste.  The pork was lean, char-grilled and very tasty.  Pepper was pleasent and noodle was a bit too thin for my liking.  Egg tasted too much of soya sauce and was too salty.  If they want to be authentic, they need to get the basics right.

RzHGZJnzZFAjAJ8anhi0JA.text: I'm always reading comments in re to the battle of the best ramen joint between Bonedaddies and Tonkotsu... Well, for me, based on the Tonkotsu ramen it's still TONKOTSU hands down. I'm always a little skeptical when going to Gaijin run Japanese joints but Tonkotsu has always been consistent in taste. Their own made noodles are just the perfect consistency, the broth has depth, it's cloudy but not fatty and oily. Egg was perfect and pork delicious. Perfect sized bowl of ramen to make you happy. I also ordered the hiyayakko tofu (chilled tofu), which definitely was super chilled, maybe a bit too chilled for my liking but had a super silky texture and was delicious with their own made chilli. Def the place to go for tonkotsu ramen. Note: they take a break between services so are shut between 3pm-5pm

FyngAnvOt2Ptn77SF3aCCw.text: Ramen isn't bad, but it's not great either. Comparing the ramen here to other's I have tried in London doesn't put this restaurant on top, but it doesn't put it on the bottom either.. It's maybe the 4th best in London.. The broth just doesn't have that really yummy taste which you associate with tonkotsu ramen. I did eat here a couple of times, but just because the restaurant is conveniently located in Soho and the ramen does satisfy a ramen crazing.I did have the salted caramel ice-cream sandwich for dessert which was very yummy! The gyoza are good too (better than gyoza's at Gyoza Bar in Covent Garden!). The interior of this restaurant is nice too. Paid £48 for 2 starters, 2 ramens, 2 soft drinks and dessert.I would recommend to come here if you're interested in the ramen that London has to offer.

photos.caption: Photo of Tonkotsu Bar & Ramen - London, United Kingdom. Tonkotsu Ramen

Wn0FBviI_sQ9Fh_JUEXF_A.text: Tonkotsu had the friendliest service out of all the Soho ramen shops I visited, which somewhat makes up for the ramen itself not being top-notch. I got the Tokyo ramen, with pork and chicken stock, classic noodles, bamboo shoots, marinated and braised pork belly, and a seasoned egg. The ingredients were on point, but the execution failed. The noodles weren't al dente enough, the meat base was overwhelmed by soy sauce, and the pork belly was dried out. Too bad, because as I said, the service is great. If you sit at the bar, you get really friendly, attentive service not just from your server, but from the cooks.

KcinDOf9P1YUt2kpnyt9nQ.text: Great ramen spot for a cold wet London day! Came here after getting up its misty outside, craving for a good bowl of ramen... then here it is.. tried three flavors: vege, seafood and original. The original blows me away, the broth is creamy and rich, the pork inside is so tasty, tender and I even ate the fatty part! The noodle is handmade and has great texture to it.. great bowl of ramen! The vege bowl is ok .. the seafood bowl has lots of crab meat inside which makes broth tastes like seafood, clean and delicious... depends on your mood but I'll always go with the original one!

My friend had the classic ramen and they were very satisfied! The noodles are very light and you won't feel weighed down after your meal just satisfied.

nkEd39TMI1V3uLrPzDTsDA.text: Having read about Tonkotsu in the press, but cross-checking it with Yelp reviews, Tonkotsu didn't make my list of places that I must try while walking around Soho.  That being said, as my fiance and I were in search of food after hitting up Milroy's for whiskey, and a pint at Dog & Duck, we found ourselves wandering around the area looking for something that would hit the spot on a chilly (but pleasant) October night.  Randomly, I came across Tonkotsu and immediately said, "WAIT! I've read about this place! Let's try it!".  Having come from San Francisco, born and raised in LA, and with someone who spends a fair amount of time in New York, both of us were ready and eager to see what Tonkotsu brought to the table from a ramen perspective.I confess that my last ramen experience in the UK was Wagamama, and I really only have one word that sums of that experience: waste of time.  So, when Tonkotsu rolled out a bowl of beautiful pork stock and thin noodles topped with slices of pork belly, half an egg, menma, bean sprouts and spring onions, I was thoroughly impressed!  The stock was more flavourful that I was expecting, and not overly salty or rich like I've had at other places.  The noodles were al dente, which is also a change from what I'm used to, but not in a bad way.  The bowls came out incredibly fast, so service here was on point.On the other hand, a few things that were a little disappointing: the egg and the pork.  The egg was not exactly soft-boiled, I'd describe it more like 90% on its way to being hard-boiled.  And, the inside of it was cold.  I definitely prefer the creamy egg with a soft-warm middle.  And then the pork.  Unfortunately I think most people here have had the same general experience with the pork where it's slightly overcooked (which I would gather gives it the "soft" texture) but lacked a lot of flavor and was sort of just chewy.A girl next to me ordered the Tokyo ramen, which also looked delicious, but it seemed fitting to order the namesake dish this time around.  Overall, not a bad place to randomly come across, I know that Tonkotsu definitely exceeded my expectations when it came down to a bowl of soup in London.

photos.caption: Photo of Tonkotsu Bar & Ramen - London, United Kingdom. Tonkotsu ramen

-pZdD8p6EkQQNZFEhjrJbg.text: There's a trifecta of Japanese/ramen shops in this part of London--Kanada ya, Koya, and Tonkotsu. The decor is eclectic and yet the feel of the place is very warm. Don't be fooled by the lack of a queue outside. The place can seat plenty. We ordered the gyoza, pork and prawns, and both were good. And all us had the house special--the Tonkotsu. The broth was rich, creamy, and spiced perfectly. Served with pork, booked egg, and spiced bamboo shoots. But the winner was the noodles. They were thin, perfectly cooked, and held the broth well. Well worth the visit.

vPcU1pSj1AcKvkmxQAuGoA.text: Oh Tonkotsu! You could be so good (apart from the Tonkotsu!)It took me a while to try this place (I was excited by the good reviews and worried by the bad reviews) I mean Andrew even gave them one star! I reserve 1 star reviews for truly crappy companies like BT, Virgin and tesco extra...how could a ramen shop possibly be that bad!?Well...it wasn't that bad, in fact, most of it was truly excellent:- 5* - The karaage chicken was gooood. You could taste all the lovely marinated flavours and it was succulent on the inside and uber crunchy on the outside. - 5* - The gyoza are handmade, so don't expect them to look pretty, but the taste was fantastic. They also provide all the right condiments If you're not sure what to do: add some vinegar, soy and spicy oil into the dipping space... then dunk before you eat. You'll look like a pro.- 4* - The Tokyo ramen was really good, almost as good as Ittenbari. The pork belly meat was lovely, the egg was squidgy (although a bit chilled) the broth was good, but better with some spice from the chilli oil.But...- 2* - Unfortunately the Tonkotsu itself was a bit disappointing. The broth has a good creamy texture, but just didn't taste of much, and the meat was chewy and fatty (but not in a melt-in-your-mouth-joy fatty way ...just tough and unpleasant)So, I liked it, but I wouldn't come back for the actual tonkotsu soup. p.s. I heard a few people ordering karaage and pronouncing it "ca-rage" with a soft g (Eeep!) Please try to say "ka-ra-a-geh" otherwise I am pretty sure somewhere-or-other Japanese chicken fairies will be dying of language-massacre-despair.
